prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling a friend he is being creepy and pathetic following a breakup?
My friend was with this girl for about eight months. He is 22.

While he was with her, he would go on and on about how she was "the one" and how they were going to get married, etc. 

She recently broke up with him because he was moving way too fast in the relationship and he needs time to work on himself and deal with his anxiety.

He completely lost it after this. We ended up having to call 911 and have him taken to the hospital because he was calling her and us threatening harm on himself. 

He constantly calls her asking why she can't take him back, and he told us that if she's in the city, he might go to her place and "ask her in person". 

Well, me and my friends all took turns spending time with him after the hospital visit and on my turn I just lost it after hearing for the fifth time how he was going to "get her back."

I told him he was being creepy and pathetic and that she has made it abundantly clear that she doesn't want to get back together with him and he needs to stop all this behavior. 

He got really pissed and kicked me out of his apartment.

My friends told me that I probably could have done it in a nicer way but that they agree with me.

So AITA for telling him all that?
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the person is in the wrong for telling their friend he's being creepy and pathetic after a breakup. Let me start by understanding the situation.

The friend was in an 8-month relationship where he kept saying she was "the one" and they'd get married. She broke up with him because he was moving too fast and needs to work on himself and his anxiety. After the breakup, the friend lost it, called 911 because he was threatening self-harm, and kept contacting the ex, even considering showing up at her place. The person in question got fed up and told their friend he was being creepy and pathetic, leading to being kicked out. Their friends agree with them but said maybe a nicer approach was possible.

So the main question is whether the person was in the wrong for confronting their friend. Let's break it down. The friend is clearly struggling post-breakup, with mental health issues (anxiety, possible suicidal thoughts). The friend's actions—calling the ex repeatedly, threatening self-harm, considering showing up uninvited—are all signs of problematic behavior. The person who spoke up did so because they were concerned about their friend's actions, which could be seen as harassment or unsafe. 

But the method of confrontation might matter. The person says they "lost it" after hearing the same thing five times, which might mean they were abrupt or not empathetic enough. Their friends suggested a nicer approach, so maybe the tone was an issue. However, the content of the message—that the friend is being creepy and needs to stop—is valid because the friend's behavior is indeed inappropriate. 

The key points here are the intent and the impact. The intent was to help the friend stop harmful behavior, which is a good motive. The impact was that the friend got angry and kicked them out. However, the friend's actions are dangerous (self-harm, stalking behavior), so the person might have a valid reason to speak up. 

In terms of responsibility, the friend is the one engaging in harmful actions, but the person who confronted them might have done so in a way that wasn't supportive enough. However, given the severity of the friend's actions, pointing out the creepy behavior is necessary. The person isn't wrong for trying to help, even if the delivery could have been better. So, I think the answer is B (Not in the wrong), as they were trying to address a serious issue, even if the method could have been improved.
